Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Power-constrained distributed vector estimation in wireless sensor networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) have the potential to significantly impact many aspects of our everyday life and are anticipated to be critically important for environmental monitoring, health monitoring, surveillance, military, and homeland security applications. Distributed parameter estimation serves as one of the main challenges in WSNs, where spatially distributed battery-powered sensors are deployed over a sensing field to monitor physical or environmental conditions. This research will investigate distributed estimation of an unknown vector with a general observation model, when the transmission strategy is digital.

The following three problems will tackled: (1) Bayesian Cramer-Rao bound (CRB) and linear estimators for hard-decoding and soft-decoding link layer designs. The Bayesian CRB will be derived and linear estimators will be developed. In hard-decoding design, the fusion center (FC) uses the recovered transmitted discrete messages for estimation, whereas in soft-decoding design, the FC uses directly the continuous-valued channel outputs for estimation. The impacts of the observation model, fading and communication channel noises and choice of modulation on the optimization solutions will be studied, and the existing tradeoffs between transmit power, rate, and estimation accuracy will be explored. Contrasting the power-rate-distortion regions will enable the investigator to quantify the performance improvement provided by soft-decoding (compared with hard-decoding) link layer design; (2) channel estimation problems in distributed vector estimation. The influence of wireless channel estimation errors on the distributed signal processing designs will be studied. Also, the investigator will study how the combined effects of channel estimation errors and energy cost of transmitting training symbols further limit the estimation accuracy; and, (3) distributed vector estimation in a cluster-based hierarchical network architecture with digital transmission. The existing tradeoffs between transmit power allocation among the clusters and the estimation accuracy will be explored.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The plethora of wireless sensor network applications, with practical constraints on network power and bandwidth, raises a series of challenging technical problems for system-level designers and engineers. One of these problems is bandwidth-constrained distributed parameter estimation problem, where geographically distributed battery-powered sensors are deployed over a sensing field to monitor physical or environmental conditions. Each sensor makes a noisy observation of the unobservable parameter to be estimated, and transmits its locally processed observation to a fusion center. The fusion center is tasked with estimating the unknown parameter, via fusing the received data from the sensors with the network. From a signal processing perspective, a major design challenge is to develop novel distributed signal processing schemes that enable an accurate estimation, subject to strict bandwidth and transmit power constraints. This challenge is further exacerbated by the adverse effect of unreliable wireless fading channels. This project develops optimal and near-optimal channel-aware distributed estimation designs, where the developed designs integrate signal processing and communication blocks, via exploiting communication channel state information. The key outcomes of this project follow.

1) Considering distributed estimation of a Gaussian vector with linear observation model, we have studied optimal and near-optimal channel-aware distributed estimation designs, under strict transmission power and bandwidth constraints. In particular, we have developed transmission power and bandwidth allotment, such that the constrained mean-square errors of linear Bayesian estimators at the fusion center are minimized. The significance of these works is to provide closed-form solutions for power and bandwidth allocation, which consequently allowed us to analyze quantitatively the behavior of the system under extreme cases of scarcity of power and/or bandwidth.

2) We have studied the fundamental limits on estimation accuracy of a distributed estimation system, when sensors' observations are contaminated with both random additive and multiplicative noises. Our contributions are the first works on understanding the effect of random multiplicative noise on the performance limits of channel-aware distributed estimation systems. In particular, we have explored the impact of quantization and the (partial) knowledge of multiplicative noise statistics on (i) the performance of Bayesian estimators (including minimum mean square error and maximum a posteriori estimators), and (ii) the estimation theoretic bounds (including Weiss-Weinstein bound and Bayesian Cramer-Rao bound).  We have characterized the conditions under which the presence of multiplicative noise can lead into an improved estimation accuracy, a phenomena which is referred to as "multiplicative noise enhancement".

3) Considering distributed estimation of a Gaussian vector with linear observation model, we have established the relationship between the mutual information (of unknown Gaussian vector and its estimate) and Bayesian Cramer-Rao bound. We have developed near-optimal channel-aware distributed estimation designs, and studied how the developed designs change as digital transmission scheme, communication channel model, and receiver type (coherent versus non-coherent) change.

4) Considering distributed estimation of a Gaussian scalar in a hierarchical power constrained wireless sensor network, we have studied the effect of channel estimation error on the achievable accuracy in estimating the unknown Gaussian at the fusion center. For linear fusion rules, we have explored the tradeoff between training and data transmit powers. We have developed methods to quantitatively measure the effectiveness of different power allocation schemes in closing the mean-square-error (MSE) performance gap, with respect to the estimation theoretic Bayesian Cramer-Rao bound. Combining these methods with our computational complexity analysis provides the system designer with quantitative complexity-versus-MSE improvement tradeoffs offered by different power allocation schemes.

5) Four undergraduate (including 2 female) students have worked on designing a mobile game application that enables adolescents to take control over their epilepsy. This application would allow its users to learn about their type of epilepsy and seizures, learn how to take their scheduled medications independently, and learn possible side effects of their medications.

The research activities supported by this project have impacts on the theory and practice of wireless sensor network technologies. We have disseminated our key findings and generated knowledge to research communities of interest, via publishing in peer-reviewed journals and refereed IEEE conference proceedings. The gained knowledge throughout this project enabled us to find new and exciting research opportunities in other disciplines, including advanced brain signal, and has been incorporated into an existing course "Adaptive Digital Signal Processing" at UCF.

In addition, this project has facilitated training the next generation of scientists and engineers that have joined and will join STEM workforce. During the course of this project, 3 PhD and 1 MS (female) students made significant scientific contributions toward achieving the goals of this project. Two PhD students have already completed their PhD studies and joined STEM workforce. The remaining PhD student is on her path to earn her PhD degree. This project also has supported the research of four undergraduate students (REU participants).
